qas.question: Who drew a difference between cadre parties and mass parties?

answers.text: political elites that were concerned with contesting elections and restricted the influence of outsiders
Mass parties tried to recruit new members who were a source of party income and were often expected to spread party ideology

qas.question: What is an example of a mass party?
What type of parties are the two major parties in the United States?
What German political scientist drew a distinction between party ideology and elections?
Who was the focus of recruitment by cadre parties?
What did cadre parties expect new members to spread?
What did cadre parties expect new members to give assistance for?
What are the two major parties in France?

context: French political scientist <a0_0><b5_0>Maurice Duverger<b5_0/><a0_0/> drew a distinction between cadre parties and mass parties. Cadre parties were <a1_0>political elites that were concerned with contesting elections and restricted the influence of outsiders<a1_0/>, who were only required to assist in election campaigns. <a2_0>Mass parties tried to recruit <b6_0>new members<b6_0/> who were a source of party income and were often expected to spread <b7_0>party ideology<b7_0/><a2_0/> as well as assist in <b8_0>elections<b8_0/>.<a3_0>Socialist parties<a3_0/> are examples of mass parties, while the British Conservative Party and the German Christian Democratic Union are examples of hybrid parties. In the United States, where both major parties were <a4_0><b9_0>cadre parties<b9_0/><a4_0/>, the introduction of primaries and other reforms has transformed them so that power is held by activists who compete over influence and nomination of candidates.
